content: for understanding brioche rib we are going to start by thinking about corrugated ribbing a two colored simple rib with k1/p1 all the way around corrugated ribbing round 4 round 3 p k p k p k p k round 2 p k p k p k p k round 1 to work corrugated ribbing you work the knits in one color and the purls in another creating vertical stripes with a k/p texture the unworked yarn is carried across the back of the work an important note here you can also work a corrugated rib by doing two passes over each row on pass one you would work only the knit stitches in your mc slipping the purl stitches with the yarn held in back on pass two you would work only the purl stitches in your cc still holding the yarn to the back why consider corrugated rib because it is very similar to brioche rib with just a few adjustments brioche rib brp sl1yo brp sl1yo brp sl1yo brp sl1yo round 4 sl1yo brk sl1yo brk sl1yo brk sl1yo brk round 3 \ \ \ \ round 2 \ \ \ \ round 1 to work a brioche rib you work two passes over each row one knit mc pass and one purl cc pass instead of holding the yarn to the back when you slip or skip the alternating stitches you carry the working yarn as a yarn over with the slipped stitch when you encounter these stitches on the next round you simply knit or purl the yarn over with the slipped stitch creating the striking brioche rib pattern thank you for choosing my pattern i love to see what you are working on so please tag me @needle fox arts on instagram or post in the needle fox arts group on ravelry © taylor rutledge 2025
